lessons.title: Browser and Client
masteryOutcomes: Define browser and client in a web page scenario
Describe what the browser does with HTML/CSS/JS at a high level
Identify what the user controls vs what the browser controls

lessons.title: Server and Response
masteryOutcomes: Define server and response
List common response files (HTML, CSS, JS, images)
Understand what it means to ‚Äúserve a file‚Äù

lessons.title: Request in Plain Words
masteryOutcomes: Define request using everyday examples (page load, image load)
Trace ‚Äútype URL ‚Üí request ‚Üí response ‚Üí render‚Äù
Predict what happens when a request fails (missing page/file)

lessons.title: URLs and Paths
masteryOutcomes: Identify URL parts: domain + path + query (conceptually)
Distinguish URL path vs local file path
Understand why correct paths matter for loading resources

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Web roles in a streaming site
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Identify and explain the roles of browser, client, and server in a familiar media streaming scenario.

lessons.title: HTML Elements

Create a page using common elements (h1, p, a)
Use headings to create a readable structure

lessons.title: HTML Elements vs Tags

Identify and understand the opening and closing tag
Identify and understand self-closing tags

lessons.title: HTML Attributes

Use common attributes correctly (href, src, alt)
Understand what ‚Äúvalue‚Äù means in an attribute context

lessons.title: Links Between Pages
masteryOutcomes: Create links between index.html and about.html

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Personal bio page
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Use basic HTML elements (h1, p, a) to structure a simple personal introduction page. Output: A single HTML file that displays a well-structured bio with a main heading, paragraphs, and at least two links.

lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Apply margin and padding intentionally on a recipe card layout and verify spacing using the browser‚Äôs box model tools. Output: A recipe card where ingredients, steps, and title are spaced cleanly using well-chosen margins and padding.

lessons.title: Simple Layout with Float
masteryOutcomes: Create a basic two-column or image+text layout using float
Clear floats to prevent layout issues
Understand how float changes normal flow

lessons.title: Buttons and Inputs
masteryOutcomes: Style buttons with hover and focus states (basic usability)
Style inputs for consistent form design
Keep button and input styles reusable via classes

lessons.title: CSS Debugging in DevTools
masteryOutcomes: Find where a style is coming from in the Styles panel
Identify why a style isn‚Äôt applying (wrong selector or wrong file)
Make a test change in DevTools, then apply it in code

lessons.title: JavaScript Adds Behavior
masteryOutcomes: Understand what JavaScript is used for on a web page
Link a script.js file correctly
Use console.log to confirm the script runs
